business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Minister, do you agree with your colleague the Minister for Community Services that there is a need to improve service standards in Centrelink? These comments were made in response to reports that 250,000 phone inquiries to Centrelink go unanswered each day. This equates to a total of over 90 million calls a year. Given those figures, how can the minister justify the decision to axe 5,000 Centrelink jobs? If Centrelink cannot answer the phones now, how does the minister expect Centrelink to cope when it has thousands less staff?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The government is determined to ensure that Centrelink provides good service to Australians. When you look at the magnitude of the task which they face, they are doing a very good job. The call centre system has run into some difficulties because of the popularity of the service. More and more people, in fact, are calling Centrelink all the time.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, there is a great deal of laughter by opposition senators about the call centre system but, since the coming of this government, there have been call centres opened right around regional Australia giving jobs to regional Australians. There has been an announcement of two call centres to be placed in rural areas for a particular focus on rural people with their special needs. Over last Christmas another 300 part-time staff were put on duty to enable the extra demand over the Christmas period to be dealt with.

answer.para: It is true to say that, most times, the call centre system is handling the calls very well. The opposition—I think maybe to help the CPSU agenda—is determined to rubbish the Centrelink staff who are, in fact, providing a very good service.

talk.start.para: —You are sacking 5,000 of them!

—The other day I was speaking to a representative of the Pensioners Union who told me how concerned she was about criticism of members of staff of Centrelink from people who should know better and that the Centrelink staff serve people very well. It is a huge job that they have.
—Does that justify sacking them?
—Order! There are far too many interjections.
—It is a fair question though.
—You can ask it at the appropriate time.

—The opposition suggests that somehow there has been slash and burn in respect of the Centrelink call centre system. In fact, the Centrelink call centre system is quarantined from cuts to employment. It is intended that the system will be expanded in several ways—as I have said, with more call centres and also with new technology which will allow more people to get through more frequently. The call centre system has been dealing with 80,000 up to 150,000 constituents or callers per day. They find it very hard when occasionally there are a million calls—not people but a million calls resulting from the use of redial buttons and suchlike. No system can cope with that and that, of course, is part of the problem.

answer.para: Centrelink is in a very similar position to some of the other big organisations in our country like banks that have also been trying very hard to encourage their customers to do business over the telephone. Their customers also find it difficult to get through to them at some times. I think all call centre operators would say that it is a matter of when you provide the facilities more and more people want to use them.

The Centrelink call centre system deserves the support of the Senate. It is providing a service. It is important that that service be improved and continued. The whole process is very much at the forefront of the government's mind in the provision of resources to the call centres and in support for the people who provide a very good service on that call centre system. I am amazed to hear the representatives of the CPSU coming into this chamber regularly pouring mud on really hardworking people who work for Centrelink. ((Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm her reported statement saying that people should simply try again or visit their local Centrelink branch? Isn't this `Let them eat cake' response a callous remark considering the problems being faced by tens of thousands of Centrelink clients who are simply unable to contact someone in that agency?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —No. I reject that utterly. I happen to have here an answer to a question which Senator Evans put on notice at the last estimates. The table that has been provided demonstrates that for 1998 the number of calls that were successfully taken by Centrelink increased by a substantial percentage for every month of the year. In 1997 the calls handled by the Centrelink call centre were 14,723,832; in 1998 it was 17,320,811. These are the people who got through and got good service. More than 17 million got that service. That was a 17.6 per cent increase over the previous year and, I call tell you, a substantial improvement over the Labor years. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Under the Howard government the Australian economy has grown strongly, providing increased job opportunities. I ask the minister: how is the government fulfilling its commitment to provide job opportunities and job security to young Australians?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —There is no more important challenge than providing jobs for Austral ians who are seeking work. This government is clearly committed, as has been demonstrated by its policies. Low inflation, low interest rates and reformed industrial relations have given business the chance to grow and expand and provide jobs. We are pleased that 370,000 new jobs have been created since this government came into office. We are pleased that the percentage of unemployment is lower than it has been for years, but we do recognise that there is still a need to do better.

answer.para: Unfortunately, our determination to do better is continually blocked by the Labor Party, which has no interest at all in reducing the numbers of unemployed in this country. It is interested only in playing the role of opposition, the role of blocking—not in a constructive way contributing to reducing the number of unemployed. We saw it in its attitude in relation to the unfair dismissal provisions for small business. Small business said that government reform could provide an extra 50,000 jobs. So what did Labor do? Labor voted it down.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is impossible for senators to hear. The breach of standing orders is intolerable and the level of noise in the chamber makes it impossible for anyone listening to hear what is happening. I would ask senators on my left to observe standing orders.
—Senator Bolkus, I have just asked senators to stop shouting.
—To vote down the chance of 50,000 more jobs in Australia is almost beyond comprehension, but that is what the Labor Party did.
—What a lie you are telling!
—Senator Cook, withdraw that remark.
—If I made an offensive remark, I withdraw it.
—Unconditionally withdraw it, Senator. I ask you to withdraw.
—Don't be such a sook.
—Senators on my right will stop interjecting. Senator Cook, I asked you to withdraw the remark.
—I thought I had, but if you think I have not, I withdraw.

—The chance of 50,000 new jobs was lost by the position the Labor Party took on the unfair dismissal provisions. It is the view of small business, but the Labor Party would never listen to the view of small business. Given the chance to act in this place to ensure the continuation of youth wage rates, to ensure the opportunity of more jobs for young Australians, what did the Labor Party do? They voted against that as well. Young Australians wanting the opportunity for work lost that opportunity yesterday when the Labor Party voted against it.

answer.para: Even Mr Carr, the Labor Premier in New South Wales, sees it differently. He said:

I think we have got to be alive to the argument that forcing up youth rates can contribute to youth unemployment. I am very conscious of the fact that any thrust in youth rates will see employers simply opt not to employ young people.
I would have thought it was obvious. Yet the Labor Party, because they are told to do so by the union movement, come in here and vote against the opportunity to create jobs for young people.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Hill is reflecting on a vote of the Senate. That is against standing orders. He is not able to reflect on a vote of the Senate. You should call him to order and ask him not to do so.
—To say that a vote is wrong and contrary to what the speaker has voted himself is not in contravention of the standing orders. It is not reflecting on a vote of the Senate.

—What is interesting is that Labor's leader in waiting, Mr Crean, apparently sees it differently from Mr Beazley. He said, `Labor does recognise that employment growth may be affected by the cost of employing young people.' He recognises it. Yet what did Mr Beazley say when Labor voted down this opportunity of more jobs for young people? He described it as a `great victory'. He said that he was really `chuffed' about the chance of voting down more jobs for young people. That demonstrates the lack of leadership, which is so clear now, within the Australian Labor Party as it searches around—the old way of Mr Beazley, the new way and then the third way. Now Mr Crean and Mr Brereton are waving the baton around and saying that they can do better than Mr Beazley.

answer.para: Anyone who is prepared to stand up for jobs for young people, for legislative reform that will provide more jobs for young people, deserves a go ahead of Mr Beazley. This government is committed to more jobs for young people and will keep introducing reforms into this parliament to achieve that goal.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The leader has enlightened us as to several initiatives that the government has sought to take in the interests of job security for young people that have been blocked by the Labor Party. Could the leader enlighten us further as to initiatives which the government has taken in addition to these which have been of benefit to young people's employment prospects?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —There have been many. Again, practically all have been opposed by the Labor Party. Remember the mutual obligations through the Work for the Dole scheme? That was opposed by the Labor Party. Our efforts to encourage young people to stay at high school so that they are more employable—no interest in the Labor Party. Our efforts to improve literacy and numeracy among young people—opposed by the Labor Party. Our enhanced apprenticeship scheme—opposed by the Labor Party. It further demonstrates that this Labor Party, focused on opposition, has no interest in providing more opportunities for young people for work or seeing that they are better qualified for jobs that might be available.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm that less than one per cent of benefit recipients from whom money is recovered are ever charged with fraud? Minister, doesn't this statistic reflect the fact that for the overwhelming majority of these recipients either Centrelink was responsible for the overpayment or the recipient was simply late in advising of a change of circumstance? Whilst the minister has been proudly touting the amounts this government has been recovering from recipients as proof of a crackdown on fraud, can she now say how much of that recovered money was actually due to Centrelink error or innocent mistakes and delays on the part of recipients? Isn't it true that only a tiny percentage of the total amount of recovered money was actually due to demonstrated fraud on behalf of the recipient?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Senator McKiernan has been in this chamber for long enough and heard me talk about this issue for long enough to know that I do not just talk about fraud. Fraud and compliance are the basis of all the reports which have been tabled in this parliament every quarter since this government came into office. Why did we table those reports every quarter? Because the previous government was not serious about cracking down on fraud and compliance.
—Oh, rubbish!
—The intelligentsia at it again!
—Nobody has suggested that the relatively small numbers of people who are actually taken through the courts are the only people who have been engaged in fraud.
—I wish your side would just tell the truth.
—I've been hoping for that for years.
—Order! Senator Newman, just a moment. Conversations across the chamber are disorderly.
—Also the number of people who are involved in the repayment of debt are not all fraudulent. Nobody has ever suggested that. I certainly have not.
—You do, regularly.

—I certainly have not. If Senator Ray is wanting to use his booming voice to shout me down again, then I would suggest that he is a bit sensitive about this issue because his government was pretty soft in this area, and the Australian people recognised that. The Labor Party recognised it in fact. When we went to the 1996 election, the Labor Party did a study afterwards as to why they lost the election. One of the elements that they thought was important in their losing the election was that they were seen to be soft on social security fraud and compliance issues. This government has done not only what is in the interests of the majority of those decent people who are drawing social security entitlements but also the right thing by the taxpayer who is funding the system. It is very important that nobody is under any misapprehension.

answer.para: The numbers of people who are taken through the courts do not represent all those people who are fraudulent—they never have—but they are the ones who are particularly diligent in their fraud. They are the ones who have taken a lot of money out of the system, often over a number of years with a very deliberate and continuous fraud. It is important that that be seen by the public as being what happens if you are not prepared to do the honest thing by your fellow taxpayers. You are taking the money out of your neighbour's pocket. It is very akin to stealing.

Senator McKiernan may not have been at Senate estimates where questions like this have been answered over the last few years. As I recall it, the figure which is consistently given by my department for the level of repayments that are required as a result of an administrative error by the department, now Centrelink, has always been under five per cent. As I stand here I seem to recall the Auditor acknowledging not long ago that recently it has been substantially lower than that.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I had hoped that the minister would take that part of the question I asked on notice and provide the details of it instead of merely relying on her memory. Isn't it true that any future increase in the total amount of money recovered from benefit recipients simply reflects a growing number of errors on the part of Centrelink, which is directly related to this government's further cutting staff numbers to do the work?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Hence the reason for the first part of the question and your disappointment that I was able to give you some hard information about the subject. The proportion of repayments that are required from customers as a result of Centrelink error is going down. I know that is a great disappointment to you because you cannot make a case, Senator.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Could the minister inform the Senate if there has been a clear consensus amongst policy makers over the last decade concerning government ownership of major business enterprises? Is the consensus based on sound and well-reasoned arguments which are accepted around the world? Has this consensus been reflected through such measures as the privatisation of Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank and Telstra? Finally, I ask the minister: is there any recent evidence that some policy makers have abandoned this consensus for cynical, short-term political opportunism?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes. The fact is that, as Senator Crane rightly points out, through the 1980s and into the 1990s there was bipartisan support for a policy of privatisation of the major government business enterprises in this country.
—Nonsense!

—Listen, son, you did not get a guernsey at that stage. You are still irrelevant, so we do not have to listen to you. The Commonwealth Bank, Qantas, Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the airports and pretty much everything that could be privatised was privatised by Labor in government. There is not much left, I admit, but Telstra is one of them. Of course, Mr Beazley, as the Minister for Finance, was in charge of most of these processes. When we corporatised Telstra, there he was as the Minister for Transport and Communications.

answer.para: What did we discover recently? According to Bob Gottliebsen in the BRW, in late 1995 Mr Keating called John Prescott to Canberra and offered to sell Telstra to BHP. Who else would just happen to have his fingerprints at the scene? None other than the then Deputy Prime Minister of Australia. Did he know or didn't he? He has never denied it, but if he does get up and deny it what does that tell you? A monumental vote of no confidence from his leader. This is his problem at the moment, you see. When you start running around calling for unity and telling people to lie down and have a Bex, you are in very big trouble. As Tony Wright pointed out, do not worry about the Breretons; worry about your own performance. That is what it is about.

The tragedy of this debate is that your leader runs around in ever diminishing circles and cannot even understand what the issues are. So this morning, when asked if there was any chance for a further sell-off of Telstra, he told Neil Mitchell, `That's in the hands of Senator Harradine at the moment.' What does `at the moment' mean? I suppose it means, `If we get into government, everything will be different.' What the public needs to understand is that if you sell now, you get Telstra lock, stock and barrel in the private sector. If you wait until Labor gets into government—if it ever happens—what you get is a fire sale break-up. In other words, all the good pieces would be flogged off and you would leave the unions with their plaything.

Mr Beazley cannot understand this. He says, `Whether it is dumped by the Senate, of course, is not in the hands of the Labor Party.' Excuse me? It's not in the hands of the Labor Party? The Labor Party has got more than the votes we would need to get this passed.

Mr Beazley is a great Civil War enthusiast, isn't he, presiding over the best civil wars on his own side of politics many a time. But he might just take a lesson from Jeb Stuart, a cavalry commander during the Civil War who went missing in action at Gettysburg. Mr Beazley is missing in action right now on all the major policy debates. The tragedy is that Mr Beazley yearns for the good old days when a good day's work meant locking yourself in your room and playing for hours on end with your model battleships and your aircraft carriers and your F111s. But it is not as easy as that in opposition. You have got to stand up for what you believe in.

We know that he believed in privatisation right down the line. He knows it is in the best interests of Australians. He knows it is the only way he can deliver $671 million worth of initiatives for rural and remote Australia. But, no, he takes the coward's way out: he sits on his hands, he lets Latham and Tanner—the young turks—get out there and argue the case. Of course, they are not opposed to privatisation. The old turkey wobbler, Mr Beazley, does not believe in any of this, does he? Of course he does. He just does not believe in sticking his head up; he is burying it in the sand. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. In terms of Telstra and the failure of the Labor Party to support this particular initiative of the government, could the minister explain to the Senate what opportunities will be denied to all Australians, in particular those in rural and remote Australia, in terms of the expansion of communications and a modern network?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —This goes to the heart of the debate, for Senator Faulkner's benefit, because only by a further sale of Telstra will you have the capacity to spend $671 million—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order with regard to standing order No. 197, interruption of a speaker.
—Well, don't take a point of order.
—I would like to hear the answer to this question because it is of enormous importance to a lot of people.
—This is not a point of order.

—Madam President, I request that you bring those on the other side of the chamber to order so that I can hear the answer, in particular Senator Faulkner and others over there, who should set an example. When it says in the paper today, `Beazley cracks whip on team, lift your game', is their interpretation of that to make more noise?
—Senator Crane, that is not a point of order. Resume your seat.

—This is a very critical issue. Does the Labor Party support continuous mobile phone coverage on 11 of Australia's major national highways? Does it support giving people local call access in outer extended zones? Does it support a broadcast fund to extend the roll-out of SBS and to clear up some of the black spots? Does it support new services in King Island and remote island communities? Does it support another $250 million for the Natural Heritage Trust? Those opposite have never said boo on the subject, they have never come out and argued against it. They know that it is the only way to fund it, but they hope no-one will notice. That is called policy gutlessness.

answer.para: As soon as your leader realises that you cannot spend the next 2½ years hoping no-one will notice, the better. You tried to get back in by doing nothing; it didn't work. Now is the time to stand up for proper policy. If you want to help the bush, if you ever want to get another seat back in rural Australia, this is the place to start. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that everyone in Western Australia was recently unable to access Centrelink services because the computer system was down? Is she aware that on 15 February this year, the computer was down for most of the morning and that Centrelink staff advised affected clients that the problem is often a national one? Does she agree that, given the size of Centrelink and the number of its clients, even if these periods last only a few hours, it will affect tens of thousands of people? During this time the efficiency of 26,000 Centrelink staff will also be drastically reduced. Can the minister inform the Senate how many times the Centrelink computer has been down over the last 12 months by state and how long those down times have lasted?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —As to the specifics at the end of the question, of course I will be happy to get that information from Minister Truss for you. But I think it would be interesting for you to know that, in a recent exercise in Western Australia, the Bunbury call centre was in fact determined to have been the most successful provider of call centre services, private or public, in the state. So I give that accolade to the people in Western Australia that your party has been rubbishing today and in the media.

answer.para: Of course systems break down. I remember when the Labor Party was in government that the Ombudsman actually reported that the teleservice clients had complained to the Ombudsman's office that they could not get through to the Department of Social Security at all over a prolonged period and that, when they could speak to anybody, they had waited for excessive periods to do so. That is why the opposition has been particularly hard on the call centre people and on Centrelink generally—because it did not have a very good track record when it was in government.

I remind the Senate that Centrelink has something like 6.2 million customers. There are eight million individual entitlements. There are 24,000 staff, providing services over 400 sites, but now extending to 1,000 where we have shared facilities with state or local government or with outreach facilities. They send 66 million letters to customers every year. They book over 400,000 office appointments every month. They will handle something like 19 million phone calls this year, and this is expected to go up to about 21 million calls next year. They make some half a million decisions each week. They have 12 million people access their Internet website each year. On-line transactions total 12.5 million every day. The number of payments total $230 million each year. I think in those circumstances, when a computer can go down from time to time, they are doing a remarkable job.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you have a backup system? Inefficient and imprudent management!
—Senator Cook, we are waiting for you to stop interjecting so Senator Bishop can ask his question.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the moves to outsource Centrelink's IT, how can the minister guarantee that under a contracted-out arrangement Centrelink will remain accountable to the parliament for the reliability of its computer system?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —This question is a worthwhile one, I must say. It was the Labor Party in government that actually started the outsourcing of IT. Senator, you were not in the parliament when the Labor government outsourced the Department of Veterans' Affairs IT programs. That was, after all, a fairly sensitive action. It was one that the opposition—and then I was the spokesman—supported your government on. The veterans were a bit concerned about it. I believe it has worked pretty well. It was the forerunner, the model, for outsourcing IT subsequently. We are not doing anything extraordinary in that way. The sorts of precautions about privacy, the accountability of the contractors and the contractual arrangements which are tied into the legislation by which, first of all, Veterans' Affairs and now Social Security and Centrelink are bound, are all operative. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the minister that the Howard government was elected in 1996 promising to bring higher standards to public life—in fact, to restore public trust in parliament. Since then: the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has failed to honour an agreement with the Democrats to abide by the outcome of a review of junior rates by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; the Prime Minister has failed to honour an undertaking to Senator Harradine that families would be compensated in the tax package for the effect of the youth allowance means test; the Minister for Family and Community Services has failed to fulfil the ironclad guarantees given by Mr Howard to ACOSS that the social security safety net would be maintained; and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has failed to keep his promise to rural Australians that Telstra's service levels would rise. I ask the minister: can you assure us here on the crossbenches that any agreements we reach with you on tax reform will actually be honoured?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —If I could interpret that with just a slight touch of optimism, I would say that I warmly welcome an indication that the Democrats might be prepared to talk seriously about the need for tax reform in this country. There is no doubt that it is long overdue. There is no doubt that a more efficient tax system will help to grow the economy, to build on the advantages that we have introduced through lower interest rates and lower inflation and better IR reform. It will give the opportunity for business to be more competitive and, therefore, to expand and to employ. If the Democrats now appreciate that fact, I applaud their recognition. This is a government that wishes to keep its promises. It is not a government that makes promises with any intention of breaking them. I think that, if an objective assessment is done on the basis of the promises that we made in the lead-up to the 1996 election, you will find that this government did, in fact, implement practically every promise it made in the first term, and the few that were left over are in the process of being implemented now.

answer.para: So, yes, we look forward to the opportunity of sitting down with the Australian Democrats and engaging in a debate which we hope will convince them of the merits of our tax proposals—tax proposals which have to be seen as a whole but which are balanced, which will result in $13 billion of tax being returned to Australians, which will result in a more efficient taxation system in relation to indirect taxes and which will result in a great advantage for Australia's export industry—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is on relevance. I asked the minister specifically about agreements reached with the crossbenches in this place and how we can get some guarantees that they are actually going to be kept.
—I cannot direct the minister on how he answers your question, but I would just draw his attention to the question that was asked and call him to continue.

—I was just demonstrating to the honourable senator why she can have faith in us on this particular issue—because the merit is on the side of the tax reform package that we have submitted to the parliament. When the Australian Democrats are convinced of that merit, there is no doubt we will have a deal that will stand the test of time and for which all Australians will be appreciative. So we welcome that discussion and an outcome that we trust will lead to that conclusion. This government does honour agreements it reaches around this chamber, and the proof of that is in our record.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister of the record. We had a written agreement with Mr Reith regarding waiting for the Industrial Relations Commission and I remind him that the minister's signature is on that agreement. Minister, I have great difficulty with the assurances—or lack of—that you have just given to us. I ask you again: on the basis that you have not kept agreements so far, either with us or with Senator Harradine, do you acknowledge that there is a need to rebuild trust between the government and the crossbenches? What measures are you going to put in place to begin that process of rebuilding trust?
—Have dinner together, and let's get on with it!

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I was going to suggest a cup of tea. I thought that was the magic formula; I thought that was the formula for success in the past. It is a serious issue. As I understand it, there was no undertaking by the government that we would not seek to bring in the same reform on youth wages, because it is important for young people to get jobs. We did not ever say we would walk away from that. We said there would be an inquiry, and there is an inquiry. If Senator Lees is suggesting to me that there was a commitment that we would not reintroduce the process until that had been completed, then I would like to see that and we will see if we can take that up with Mr Reith. But it is not as I understand the situation to be.

answer.para: I reiterate: this government does stick by its deals. It is important that there is trust within this chamber, and we would like to deal with you on that basis in contributing to delivering to this country a better tax system.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm that over Christmas last year Centrelink made overpayments of up to $800 to some 37,000 clients? Can she confirm that each client was saddled with a debt that must be repaid, a potentially disruptive situation for low income earners? Does the minister stand by the government's explanation that this bungle was caused by human error within Centrelink? Will she state on the record whether she believes that her government's decision to cut 5,000 jobs from Centrelink has made this kind of error more or less likely to occur in the future?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —As Senator Evans would know full well, these are questions which were raised and answered by officials at the estimates committee hearings. Therefore, the answer to the first question is yes and to the second question is yes, they must be repaid. Of course, a lot of people will not have spent the money. They were notified in pretty quick time. The answers that I am giving you now are ones that you were given at the time of the Senate estimates committee.

answer.para: I would like to take issue with you that in fact the decision about changes to the jobs in Centrelink was not a government decision; it was a decision of the Centrelink board. It was a decision of the Centrelink board because at the time—opposition members are not very interested in policy matters, so they may not have studied this—Centrelink was established as a statutory authority, which meant the bringing together of two organisations into one, it was clearly stated that there would be efficiencies from bringing them together and that an efficiency dividend would be expect ed, although it would not be expected in the first year of its operations.

The board made its decisions based on the recommendations of its chief executive and her senior executives. The 5,000 people who keep being peddled around is a misleading figure, just as the opposition is constantly using misleading figures to embellish their arguments that otherwise would not hold water. The number of people who were to be made redundant at the time the announcement was made was something in the order of half that number because people had already chosen to leave and take a package before the announcement. Senator NEWMAN

subdebateinfo.title: Naval Ammunition Facility: Twofold Bay, New South Wales

talk.start.para: —My question goes to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Firstly, as a preamble, the naval armaments complex has moved out of Sydney following a decision in 1994 that that would happen by the Olympic year for reasons of safety. Port Wilson in Victoria was chosen with Port Alma near Rockhampton chosen as an option. Twofold Bay at Eden was dismissed for reasons of public safety and cost. Has the government now decided to go ahead with part of that complex at Twofold Bay? If so, is there to be a waiver on public safety due to this facility being so close to the town and people in that region? talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The question relating to the potential for Twofold Bay as an ammunition facility is very important. When I was shadow minister for defence, I was very concerned at the decision made by the previous government to move the ammunitioning facility to Point Wilson. I was interested to see in the briefing note here that in December 1997 the Department of Defence referred to parliament the proposal to construct this facility at Point Wilson but the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works was concerned at the distance of Point Wilson from the Sydney fleet base and exercise area and recommended in its report on 30 June last year that Defence examine alternative locations closer to Sydney for the Navy's ammunitioning requirements. In particular, it identified Twofold Bay near Eden as a suitable location. I, of course, was not on that commit tee, but I agree wholeheartedly with its recommendations.

answer.para: I do not have all the answers today that you would like, but I can take some on notice and give you the rest. The preliminary feasibility studies, I understand, indicate that Twofold Bay on the south coast of New South Wales is suitable for construction of a Navy ammunitioning facility comprising a new wharf and jetty and several storage and administration buildings, and the potential exists for commercial use of the new wharf and jetty.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —As I indicated earlier, I will get additional information, where it is available, from the Minister for Defence. To the best of my ability, I will get the senator additional information.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Regional Ser vices, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. subdebateinfo.title: Australian Customs Service: Prohibited Weapons Imports

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs. The Australian Customs Service, which is responsible for ensuring the integrity of our national borders, has recently played an integral role in record drug seizures. In light of that latest positive work, the minister may be aware of a recent newspaper article which criticised Customs for allowing in prohibited weapons. What is the minister's response to that article?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for her question. The Commonwealth's role in relation to dangerous weapons is to enforce import restrictions. Under schedule 2 of the Customs Prohibited Imports Regulations, there is a very extensive list of weapons that are prohibited unless special permission is received. That means that, except in some very limited circumstances—and they are limited—items on that schedule are prohibited imports. That list closely represents the list of prohibited weapons for possession under state legislation throughout Australia, including New South Wales. It is not exactly the same, but it is a close parallel.

answer.para: I was, therefore, amazed to see the article that Senator Payne refers to in the Sun-Herald on 21 February, which pictured a range of weapons that are listed in schedule 2 and claimed that Customs were allowing the importation of these weapons. I think I recall a headline to the effect of, `Take your pick'. These claims are simply incorrect and misleading.

Customs have advised me that, based on a careful examination of the photographs in the newspaper, most, if not all, of the weapons are prohibited imports under Commonwealth regulations. Further, one of the knives—a particularly unattractive knife with a curved blade and spiky things that come out of the handle you hold it by—looked very similar, and I am advised that the same knife on the front page of the Sun-Herald was seized by Customs and lent to the New South Wales Police Service. What an ironic twist of fate in an election that Customs lends a weapon in good faith as an example of a dangerous weapon that they are in fact seizing and the next thing we know, in a New South Wales election context, the weapon is on the front page of the Sunday paper as an example of weapons that Customs let in. I have here the letter from the New South Wales Police Service requesting that the article be given to them.

It is true that Customs officers can only legally seize goods that are prohibited by Commonwealth regulations. The Ombudsman has, on occasion, rightly criticised Customs officers for being overzealous. Law enforcement agencies should always stay within their jurisdictional limits.

As Customs minister, I am always open to suggestions from states and territories as to the types of items they think should be added to the schedule. Where there are weapons that a state has banned the possession of but the importation is not banned, I look to speedily amending the Customs regulations where we can get state agreement. There will always be one state that wants to be tougher than another, but we will happily look at suggestions put forward by the states.

What I am sure Senator Payne realises is that this little exercise was drummed up in New South Wales as an election initiative to make the Carr government look good. I would like to take the opportunity in the remaining minute and such other time as might be available to put this in context for you, Madam President, because I know it is important you understand the real facts of crime in New South Wales. I can assure you that Customs is not letting prohibited weapons in on a day-to-day basis. The Carr government don't want you to know that they have the highest crime rate in the nation. They don't want you to know that armed robberies have more than doubled in the last three or four years, and the same with unarmed robberies. They certainly don't want you to know that assaults in New South Wales have increased by 44 per cent since 1995. They wouldn't want you to know that, would they? Furthermore, New South Wales has the lowest rate of finalised investigations of armed robbery of any state. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Are there any other matters in the Commonwealth-state discussions which pertain to this issue which the minister might advise the Senate of?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for her question. Yes, Senator Payne, I think what is important when the states and Commonwealth come to discuss these matters is that we look at the role the states are playing in law enforcement. The message I would take to such a meeting would be that it is unacceptable for New South Wales to have the lowest rate of finalised investigations of armed robbery of any state. I see Premier Carr saying he does not need more police; I see the Police Commissioner saying he does not need more police. But when you know that they have the lowest rate of finalised investigations of armed robbery of any state, you have to ask yourself, `Why don't they?' They have the lowest rate of finalised investigations of unarmed robbery.

answer.para: We should have used this next fact yesterday on International Women's Day. They have the lowest percentage of offenders proceeded against in sexual assault cases—only 25 per cent in New South Wales. If they don't need more police, I do not know what is wrong with them.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr seems to know a lot about it. Someone suggested he might have got his degree from that university by mail order. I cannot add any more to the answer I gave previously. Although my colleagues can understand it, you have to apparently say it over and over again for it to get within the thinking capacity of the opposition.

Senator IAN MACDONALD

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Mackay asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services regarding the long-term operating plan of Sydney airport. Mr Anderson has provided me with the following answer.

speech.para: The minister is aware of the letter from the Chief Executive of Airservices Australia, Mr Bill Pollard, sent to a number of organisations including the Sydney Airport Corporation at the end of last week. The letter canvasses the option of Airservices Australia handing over the runway selection to the Sydney Airport Corporation. Mr Pollard's letter does not set out the views of the government, and the government does not agree with the option canvassed in the letter. Airservices Australia has statutory responsibility for air traffic control and the carrying out of the long-term operating plan for Sydney airport. Airservices Australia will continue to be responsible for air traffic control and runway selection at Sydney airport.

Senator Mackay also asked me about the comments that were made by my colleague the member for Bradfield, Dr Nelson. I am advised that Dr Nelson agrees with the minister's position set out in this answer.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government (Senator Ian Macdonald) to questions without notice asked by Senator Carr today, relating to the accreditation of Greenwich University, Norfolk Island.

The Senate today heard an astounding farce from this minister who is quickly becoming known as the Basil Fawlty of this government for the way in which he has approached his responsibilities to Australia's international education industry. His actions—and his actions alone—in directing the Administrator of Norfolk Island to give assent to the bill for the Greenwich University has placed in jeopardy Australia's very valuable international education industry which is now running to the value of over $3 billion a year.

We have a proposition from this government which essentially argues that they do not understand what is going on. They have no idea as to what is happening within Australia's education industries and, quite clearly, have no appreciation of the damage that is being done. This minister is one who, when asked a question, throws his hands in the air and basically says, `We know nothing.'

It is a case where the minister for education, on the other hand, will argue the Manuel defence. He says that this is the responsibility of the minister for territories, while the minister for territories says that this is the responsibility of the minister for education. The vice-chancellors argue that this is a problem for the vice-chancellor of this so- called new university at Greenwich in Norfolk Island. We would have thought that anyone with any brains at all on the question of education would have asked a few basic questions about an application from an outfit like this at Greenwich.

We have a situation where this university quite clearly has been established for some time in various forms in various states in the United States of America where it has been removed from one state after another after various questions have been asked about the irregularities under which it operates. This is an extremely serious matter. If it was not quite so serious, I am sure it would be very funny.

We have to ask: did this minister make some basic inquiries, particularly about the organisation that was setting itself up as a proprietary company to run a university? Frankly, under this model, the company University Meats—which is based in Melbourne, just around the corner from my office—could operate a university because it has the name `University' in its title. This is the way in which they run their education policies in this country.

What we have here is a chancellor presenting himself as a distinguished academic. He says that, amongst his many titles, he has claims to being the Regent of the French Royal House of Anjou. He says that he is a Justice of the Peace and a Knight Grand Cross of the Sovereign Order of St John. He says that he has various titles associated with St John of Malta as a result of his activities as a great international academic.

This is the same Mr Walsh who, as I say, has his qualifications from a university which gives accreditation from the Shoshone tribe of Nevada. He presents himself as Duke de Branagh. He runs the Brimeyer organisation that has set out to support the claims that are being made to the Russian throne by His Highness Prince Alexis II. It has a post-office box address in Norfolk Island as well. So it is a very versatile operation that he is running there.

Mr Walsh, as I say, styles himself as `Duke de Branagh and de Ronceray' and describes Norfolk Island as `a former British colony, now a parliamentary monarchy, located in the Pacific Ocean'. As I say, what we have here is extremely serious. However, the government's actions suggest to me that it is being treated as a complete farce. The minister quite clearly does not understand his responsibilities. We have a situation where quite clearly the Greenwich University, while having headquarters in Hawaii, does not seem to have any accreditation in the state of Hawaii. We have a situation where a university has been running a mail-order company, with a Weetbix-packet university degree coming out of Missouri and has been presenting itself as an Australian university.

That is the great tragedy of all of this: it has been allowing itself to be presented as an Australian university. We have a university claiming to be part of the great Australian quality education system which is appropriating the names of other great institutions throughout the world, such as the International Institute of Advanced Studies in Japan and the University of Greenwich in the United Kingdom. We have a government that quite clearly does not understand its responsibility to protect the institutions in this country, the 38 universities of this country, that do a very fine job.

We have seen the Victorian government face up to its obligations—and I must suggest to the Senate that that is rare for me to say—and say, `This is not on.' This is a rort and quite clearly it is inappropriate for the government to allow it to go on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This again just shows how far this opposition is off the main game. Yesterday in the GST debate we heard those opposite going on about boy scouts, and they were two weeks out of date on that. Today, on this issue with Greenwich University, Senator Carr is off the main game as well. He did bring this matter up in estimates. But that they would bring up this obscure remote situation just shows how little material they have to work on in attempting to attack this government.

speech.para: As a matter of fact, Senator Carr has brought this up in the wrong parliament. This is not a matter for the federal government; this is a matter for state and territory governments. You should know, Senator Carr, that the legislation for the operation of universities in this country is controlled by the states and territories.

I would just refresh your memory on territory universities. In this territory we have Canberra University; who controls that, Senator Carr? All the legislative requirements, all the approvals are with the Australian Capital Territory. Then there is the territory of Norfolk Island. Who, Senator Carr, controls the authorities for the curriculum and approval in that particular territory? It is not a matter for the Commonwealth government.

You did mention—and it has also been mentioned in the process by Senator Macdonald—that this matter has been referred to MCEETYA. We are very early down the track on the whole approval process. The Norfolk Island Administrator has to give assent. It has been referred to MCEETYA to have a look at. As yet we have not had advice back from MCEETYA on this. In the final analysis, it would be up to the Governor-General to disallow this going ahead. But we are not anywhere near that stage at present.

What is the real fear here, Senator Carr? We have, as was set up under your government, what you call the National Unified System. We have Australia's accredited universities operating under the National Unified System, and Greenwich University is not a member of that. You seem to be implying that this will have some effect on Australia's reputation. I would respond by saying that that university will not be part of the Australian system unless it is accepted under the rules of the AVCC, and that may not happen. This is all speculation.

If the university were up and operating, giving degrees, and it had been proved that the sorts of courses it was giving were not up to scratch, it might be the time to perhaps bring it up in this chamber. But I think you are well ahead of time, Senator Carr. We are absolutely nowhere near that stage of operation.

Senator Carr, you have made several rubbishings of the chancellor of this institution. You should understand that there is a difference between a chancellor and a vice-chancellor: a vice-chancellor runs a university; a chancellor is always a figurehead, often a prominent person in the community. I am sure that, if we went through the records, apart from some very distinguished chancellors—such as the Chancellor of the Southern Cross University, who has eminent qualifications—many others in the positions of chancellor and pro-chancellor do not necessarily have those qualifications and are just distinguished community citizens. Possibly what you have brought up there is a total furphy.

I think we need to go back and look at the main issue here, and that is the standard of Australia's universities, which are top rate. Throughout the world, we have a reputation that is second to none in terms of a very fine and comprehensive university system. We have an export market in education and our 36 universities are now bringing in over $3 billion in funding. That is done through excellence and the quality accreditation processes that we have in place in this country.

If this particular university in the end does not come up to scratch, it will not be part of that comprehensive system, it will not be able to join the Australian Vice Chancellors Committee, it will not be part of the Unified National System. It will not have that recognition.

So, Senator, you have jumped the gun, but I appreciate why. It is because this opposition does not have sufficient matters to raise against this government. It grasps at straws. It criticises what is happening with boy scouts. It criticises Norfolk Island. Get back on the main game. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is a matter of great concern for the Senate. I was very interested to hear Senator Tierney comment that this is not a matter for the Commonwealth. I would remind Senator Tierney that Minister Ellison yesterday, in this very chamber, said:

speech.para: I understand that the minister for education has instructed the department to undertake a rigorous examination of Greenwich University to assist him in forming a view on the minister's request—
that being the Norfolk minister—
to include Greenwich University in the AQF registers.

If that is not Commonwealth involvement, I do not know what is. Further, Minister Ellison revealed yesterday—and I quote again—that he understands that `the Greenwich University's web site has changed' and it now has gone from being fully accredited, which it was marketing itself as previously, to self-accrediting. Minister Ellison, unprecipitated by this side of the chamber, indicated that the university had changed its web site. I wonder why that happened. I will tell you why it happened.

talk.start.para: —You know, do you?

—Yes, I do. The government was advised that the Greenwich University was marketing itself as a fully accredited Australian university on its web site. The government did not know that before. The government did not realise that. When it was brought to the government's attention in the estimates committees, it got on to Greenwich University, or more likely the Norfolk Island Administrator.
—The Prime Minister's friend.

—The Prime Minister's friend, thank you, Senator Carr. The government obviously said this mob is not fully accredited. You had better change your advertising, because it is incorrect, and go back to self-accrediting. If that is not an admission that this government has made a mistake, I do not know what is. I will leave the remainder to my colleagues.

speech.para: Then we have the absolutely extraordinary behaviour of Senator Macdonald during estimates where he simply refused to allow his department to answer questions in relation to this matter. He would not let them answer questions. We have Minister Kemp in the other place, Minister Ellison in the Senate on one side and way over the other side in relation to this debate we have Minister Macdonald and everybody running 5,000 miles away as fast as they can from his decision.

Minister Macdonald made a decision in December last year which was wrong. Dr Kemp knows it and Minister Ellison knows it. Otherwise, why would they now put in place a rigorous examination and involve MCEETYA in the process? What I think happened was that Minister Macdonald received the request. He made some very perfunctory investigations—although we were not illuminated as to quite what they were—in relation to the matter. He would not allow his departmental officials to respond to the questions, and he went ahead and gave it the tick. He went ahead and gave it the tick far too early. That has now been recognised by not only the Victorian state minister for education but also the federal minister for education and Minister Ellison.

talk.start.para: —And the AVCC.

—And the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. That is correct, Senator Carr. You can always tell when the government has made a mistake because it is either the bureaucrats' fault or it is the staffers' fault. In this case, it is Senator Macdonald's fault, but it is not Dr Kemp's fault and it is not Minister Ellison's fault. There is absolutely no doubt that Senator Macdonald made a decision before taking full consultation, and I suspect that the relevant education ministers are now hurriedly scurrying around attempting to ensure that it is rectified.
—The horse has bolted, though. That is the problem.

—Indeed, Senator Carr. It is too late. The approval has already been given. It is not a matter of a straight rubber stamp from the federal minister in relation to Norfolk legislation at all. What Senator Macdonald kept repeating over and over again was that legislation that emanates from Norfolk Island that he approves only applies to Norfolk Island. If Senator Macdonald can give us the assurance that only the people who live on Norfolk Island will be using Greenwich University, I think we would be happy with that.

speech.para: The reality is that the very time he gave that approval Greenwich University was on the Internet advertising itself as a fully accredited university. This is a mistake. That was a mistake from the very beginning. The investigations were not thoroughly carried out, and you can see that in relation to Minister Ellison's attitude and Dr Kemp's attitude. There is no doubt that Senator Macdonald should reverse his decision. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am delighted that today's question time and this debate of taking note of answers is being broadcast, because it will bring home to the Australian people that the Labor Party—those who would pretend to be the alternate government of this country—are not concerned about the real issues. The real issues are those that Senator Tierney addressed at the end of his speech. I am delighted to be able to follow on from the contribution of my friend and colleague Senator Tierney.

speech.para: When was the last time that we heard a question or a sensible debate in this place initiated by the Australian Labor Party in relation to interest rates, budget deficits, unemployment or industrial relations? There is absolute silence from the other side, because they know they are a policy vacuum when it comes to those fundamental issues. I could include tax reform in that. You will recall that we went to the election with a policy of tax reform. So did Labor. Labor have since dumped all their tax reform proposals, including their shadow Treasurer, Mr Evans. The Labor Party have been scurrying around during question time of late trying to find issues of no real consequence to try to somehow develop into the issue of the day so they have something to talk about, because without these side issues they would be completely and utterly devoid of issues to take before the Australian people.

I would suggest to those honourable senators opposite that, if they were genuinely concerned about the reputation of the universities of Australia and the tertiary institutions of Australia, they would join with us in removing one of the biggest blots on tertiary education in this country—that is, compulsory student unionism. If they were genuine about protecting the reputation of these institutions, they would be saying to us, `We agree with you. We will join with you in removing this blot known as compulsory student unionism.'

Individuals are forced to pay a student union fee and, if they do not, they are denied an education. We have in our industrial relations legislation, thank goodness, removed the no ticket, no start regime which the trade union officials that sit opposite so overwhelmingly embraced during their term in government. We were able to remove that. Similarly, the no ticket, no start mentality should be removed from university life in this country. But, no, the Australian Labor Party are quite happy to continue with that huge blot on the life of tertiary institutions in this country, because they know that they are the financial beneficiaries of those compulsory student union fees. So they will not be interested in making any changes in that area.

talk.start.para: —How? How will we become the beneficiaries?

—Senator O'Brien leads with his chin and he asks the question: how does the Labor Party become the beneficiary? For example, in Mr Hardgrave's electorate, which I believe is Moreton, the student union spent $40,000 of compulsorily acquired student fees to directly campaign against him. Senator O'Brien asks the question, and I have given one example. Do you want some more?
—And $60,000 dollars in Tasmania.

—And $60,000 in my home state of Tasmania. If you want some more examples, Senator O'Brien, I am more than happy to give them to you. But the bottom line in relation to this whole discussion is that Norfolk Island is an external territory of Australia. Greenwich University is the responsibility of the Norfolk Island minister responsible for higher education. That is basically the situation. The Labor Party are trying to whip this up into some sort of frenzy.
—We're talking about Australia's international reputation.

—I can tell you, Senator Carr, that overseas students are flocking to universities in Western Australia, which is the only state that does not have compulsory student unionism. Why? It is because the international reputation of Western Australian universities is such that they are flocking over there, because the blot of compulsory student unionism was removed in that state by a far-sighted state government. We are going to do the same federally. (Time expired)

—Senator Abetz can never help himself. Whenever he gets an opportunity he has to have a swipe at student unions. I was at the launch of a publication in Hobart recently about the history of the University of Tasmania student union. The photos around the wall of members of that union and the participants at the function included eminent and prominent Liberal members of state parliament and federal parliament, and they seemed to want to participate in the activities of those organisations.

speech.para: But, of course, that is a great digression from what this debate is about. I suppose I can understand Senator Abetz trying to change the subject because the fact of the matter is that what we have here is a minister who directed the Administrator of Norfolk Island to give assent to legislation which would allow this organisation to set up what can only be described as a questionable educational organisation which, apparently, through its activities provides degrees in consciousness studies, depth psychology, new mysticism and applied ecopsychology.

Perhaps they are all very valid courses, but one wonders why this organisation setting up on Norfolk Island has 101 people listed on their staff but only two have addresses in Norfolk Island. And why, when you look at the very shady background and claims by the chancellor, Mr Walsh, didn't the minister take the appropriate steps and investigate and determine that this is an organisation that needed a lot more looking into before he was going to exercise his power as the minister to direct the Administrator of Norfolk Island to give assent to the legislation to allow them to set up? That is the issue here.

Every time the opposition calls this government or its ministers to account—because making the government accountable is part of the reason we are here—the government senators opposite seem to suggest that we are not asking the right questions. We are not asking the right questions for them, because they are too hard. And we heard Senator Macdonald today duck a number of questions because he does not have an answer to the questions that are put to him. When you really analyse the actions that he took in this matter, they are indefensible. And obviously he did not do his homework before he made the direction, which he is empowered to do as the minister, to direct the Administrator of Norfolk Island to give assent to that legislation in relation to this organisation.

talk.start.para: —It has brought the rest of the universities into disrepute in the process.

—Senator Carr reminds me of course that this university purports to be part of the network of higher education in this country. This government has a duty to protect the reputation of our higher education system, and they have pointed out to us on many occasions the millions and millions of dollars that the Australian public commits to the system—billions of dollars, in fact. Yet this minister is so cavalier as to take an action without proper regard for what he is doing, which can have the effect of bringing down or damaging the international reputation of our university system.

speech.para: I would say that in my state the University of Tasmania places some reliance on attracting students from overseas for its very viability. I do not think there is any doubt about that, and I am sure that is the case for a great many universities around this country. Any action of this government which damages the credibility of the Australian university system is an action which has to be deplored. If the government is not prepared to deal with a minister who can do that, then it is up to the opposition to expose that to the Australian public.

talk.start.para: —If ever we needed evidence that the Labor Party is really off their game here in this chamber we only need to listen to the debate today. They have really narrowed their target down now—to a minister on Norfolk Island. Norfolk Island does not have any more than 1,300 permanent residents, and it is 14 square kilometres of one of our external territories. That is who you are now picking on. You are picking on the Pitcairners, the Fletcher Christians of this world. That is your new target. That is how far off the game you are. How pathetic! What is more, Senator Carr shows a distinctive ignorance of this territory and the status of Norfolk Island under the Norfolk Island Act. It has a very unique role. Though it is a territory of Australia, it plays a very unique role within our parliamentary system—and within the education system, for that matter.

speech.para: Did you know, Senator Carr, it has an independent—and a fiercely independent—administration? Therefore, establishing the Greenwich University has always been the responsibility of the Norfolk Island minister and, in particular, of the Norfolk Island education minister.

We have a fierce reputation to uphold in this country in respect of our university system. We know it is a $3.3 billion industry that has well over 150,000 international students. We do not intend to compromise that. That is why the minister, as he stated in the parliament, is going to place a rigorous examination on Greenwich University so that he can be informed. The department will be undertaking that particular examination and, as a first step, the department has written to the Norfolk Island minister asking for documentation to demonstrate Greenwich University's claims. So, before it can become embedded in the Australian university system, it has to pass that rigorous test. But, as far as their having the ability to establish the university, that is the business of the Norfolk Island government. As far as their attempting to get accreditation on the mainland, the minister has already stated quite clearly what he intends to do there.

It is the responsibility of the Norfolk Island minister for higher education in the same way as it was the responsibility of the Western Australia minister when the well-known and successful Notre Dame University was established. It is the same with the University of New England. All these new universities that have been established have been the responsibility of the local authorities. So you are barking up the wrong tree. You have now decided to target Norfolk Island. You have gone completely offshore.

talk.start.para: —I will target Senator Macdonald.

—I can assure you, Senator Carr, that this is not the direct responsibility of Minister Macdonald. You are missing the target completely. And as Senator Abetz clearly said: why haven't you raised issues of greater substance than this, for heaven's sake? Why aren't you debating the question of compulsory student unionism? Why aren't you protecting the reputation of our universities in regard to compulsory student unionism and the misrepresentation of union fees for well over 30 years—in all the time you were hanging around the university cafe, Senator Carr?

Therapeutic Goods Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999)
Amendments are proposed to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Act 1997 to implement reforms to the regulation of complementary medicines.

talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 March 1999, from Senator Chris Evans:

interjection.para: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
