subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Aquatic Air Pty Ltd

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

Labor welcomes the tabling of the Skehill report. It has been some time coming. This is unfortunate because these sorts of delays do not promote confidence in what is a critical issue—that is, air safety. In fact, delays of this length have created suspicion as to what may well be contained in them. There are a number of other documents that we are waiting on. The regulation of air safety needs confidence and trust and we cannot afford any lack of transparency with regard to air safety.

There are, as I said before, a number of other documents that ought to be tabled. One return to order went through the Senate today in relation to the Hawke review into Airservices Australia. We are very happy that that has gone through. There is another document that we will be moving the return to order on in the next sitting week, and that is the Hawke review into Airservices Australia, BASI and CASA which was inaugurated by the minister in terms of the events of late last year. We will be moving the return to order in relation to that matter next week. As I said yesterday when we were dealing with the disallowance motion of the civil aviation regulations which would have meant the privatisation of air traffic control services in Australia—we are very pleased that that disallowance was knocked off—we do need transparency. We need a clear view of all the issues relating to air safety and we need to build and strengthen public confidence in air safety.

Coming specifically to the Skehill report itself, it is very clear from the report that South Pacific Seaplanes was a problem for CASA. There were `frequent and repeated breaches of various regulatory requirements' and `a failure to honour the numerous undertakings it gave to remedy perceived inadequacies in its methods of operation'. There was a significant turnover of chief pilots. Serious allegations were made against senior management and its attitude towards safety. CASA received at least 21 complaints against SPS and it issued 13 non-compliance notices and grounded SPS aircraft. SPS aircraft were involved in a number of the accidents or alleged near accidents over the five-year period covered by the Skehill report.

By April 1997 the situation was so serious that the CASA regional manager of the south-east region at the time, Mr Diamond, issued a notice to SPS requiring them to show why their air operator's certificate or their licence to operate should not be cancelled. Following an informal conference with the SPS management, no further action was taken on this matter. This decision was taken without meaningful consultation with the flying operations inspector that was assigned to SPS. Mr Skehill makes the comment in his report that the flying operations inspector that was assigned to SPS had the most intimate knowledge of the SPS operations and had been the one who had recommended the suspension or cancellation of the AOC.

Some senators may not be aware that flying operations inspectors are experienced professional pilots who are employed to regulate pilot standards in Australia. They are critical to the whole field of aviation safety. Flying is not like riding a bike: you do forget, you do fall behind if you do not retain your skills and knowledge, and obviously the best way to do this is to practise. However, the pilot community is greatly concerned that CASA has taken the decision to downgrade the ongoing skill maintenance program for flying operations inspectors. This has undermined their skills confidence and their credibility. And we are also obviously concerned about the major cost cutting measures that CASA has instituted.

I have a number of other remarks to make in relation to this report. I see that time is running out, so at the end of my remarks I will seek leave to continue my remarks later. Suffice to say that this report contains much that we are interested in—not only us but all members of the public, particularly those who regularly use planes. We welcome the government's somewhat tardy, but at least there, initiative in terms of the tabling of this report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Actions Arising from the Skehill Report

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

There are a couple of points that I wish to make at this juncture in relation to the Skehill report. This report details CASA's response to recommendations made in the Skehill report. There were a number of issues raised in the recommendations that are cause for concern, such as the use of borrowed air operators' certificates. This has been an issue for some time and CASA now believes that it has been successfully addressed by CASA itself.

The insistence by CASA on the use of a senior pilot where the chief pilot is considered inexperienced is noted by CASA to be in fact inconsistent with the Civil Aviation Act. The Skehill report recommends the removal of the ambiguity about the action to be taken where an operations manual is seen to be unsatisfactory. CASA believes, obviously, that its house is basically in order in this matter but is seeking some legislative amendments to assist to clarify the situation.

CASA's previous policy was not to allow the transaction of substantive business by e-mail. As for the recommendation that the policy is to be changed, with back-up systems to be put in place to ensure consistency and reliability, we believe that that is all for the best and is something that ought to be instituted.

We also note that CASA has moved to ensure that proper records are taken of important meetings which lead to significant decisions and that reasons for decisions in fact be recorded. This clearly was not always the case with regard to events surrounding the SPS saga, and in fact I have to say was not the case with regard to events surrounding the cancellation of the G class airspace trial. I think that those events have been of considerable public comment, and here again we welcome CASA's intention in this regard.

A number of the actions are due to be completed by 31 March and we ask that the minister responsible, Minister Anderson, provide updates to us as soon as practicable to ensure that they, firstly, have been implemented and, secondly, have a time line in relation to completion. We believe that that is important on a number of fronts, so we make that request.

Obviously, CASA has some intricate safety systems and checks, but despite all preparations and all goodwill, with systems in place, things can go wrong. That is why we believe, as we have indicated a number of times, in the notion of openness and transparency and in the notion of openness in relation to recording of decisions and release of minutes and so on. We welcome, as I have indicated before, CASA's response to this. We reiterate our position, which has been made clear on several occasions by us, that CASA itself should always be open to review.

Clearly there were systems problems and there were areas that could be improved. As we have said publicly on a number of occasions, we think that the government could go further and ensure that the public has a clear view of what is going on in the regulation of air safety. Here again, we are keen to ensure that the government complies with today's Senate decision in terms of the tabling of the Hawke report into Airservices Australia, and we are keen that the Senate support our motion in the next sitting week with regard to the Hawke report into Airservices Australia, CASA and BASI and the issue of air safety. That report is critical and it has been with the minister for many months now.

The government needs to understand that the issue of air safety is one in which the public will not tolerate any lack of transparency; it is simply too important. We believe that the government can ameliorate this increasing perception in the community by the production of these documents and ensuring openness. Trust is earned by being open and there is no reason to hide matters. As I said, we are pleased that, after some considerable period of time, this report has finally arrived. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation: Investigation Report 9802830

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

This document records the BASI investigation into what was a tragic accident and is, in fact, the third document in the series that has been tabled here today concerning the South Pacific Seaplanes issue.

The BASI report found that a number of matters contributed to the tragedy—issues such as organisational deficiencies, the management and conduct of the charter operations and the regulation of those operations by CASA. According to this report, issues such as inadequate safety defences also contributed, and a number of local factors were identified, including poor weather conditions, a lack of formal procedures to provide safe methods of operation and commercial pressure.

There are some things that obviously cannot be helped. The weather, for example, is something that cannot be helped. But what can be helped is the identification of safety deficiencies in the company concerned and also in the regulator. That is obviously a matter of concern to everybody. Here again, we have a difficulty—as has been identified by others as well—with the dual role of the regulator with respect to both making and enforcing the regulations in relation to air safety in Australia.

I also note again with interest the issue of Airservices Australia—not CASA in this case—being extremely concerned in relation to air safety at Sydney airport and requesting that the issue of runway identification be a matter for the corporation itself rather than Airservices Australia. We believe this is a real signal that there is a difficulty with air safety in Australia and is something that ought to be taken up. Here again, I will put in another plug: in the next sitting week, we will be moving for the tabling of the Hawke report—this one not into Airservices, because we have already carried that one today—in relation to CASA, BASI and Airservices Australia and the interrelationship between the three agencies and how they operate in relation to air safety.

As I said yesterday in the disallowance speech, the events at the estimates committee hearing into the Department of Transport and Regional Services—aviation, specifically, and CASA and BASI and so on—showed that there is a clear problem. I will not remind the Senate of some of the intemperate remarks made by the chair of CASA but, suffice to say, there has been a reaction from certain members of the public to the committee as a result. I will not take that any further until we have sought advice in relation to them.

BASI's reputation, I think it would be fair to say—and probably the least one could say—was attacked at the estimates hearing, and we look forward to the public release of the review into BASI that the minister has announced. We are pleased that the government has indicated that that review will be made public, and we are hoping that it will exonerate the role that BASI played and perhaps lead to a number of proactive resolutions. We have the terms of reference into the BASI report, and we have an assurance from the government that it will be publicly available. When that is publicly available, I suspect I will take note of that document at length. I do not intend to continue further in relation to this matter. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

In moving that the Senate take note of the Austrade annual report 1997-98, I just want to take the opportunity to say a few words about the Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement which was tabled in the parliament last month.

The Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement is the annual report card to parliament and the Australian people on our export successes and the challenges that lie ahead, and Austrade is an initial part of that effort. As an island nation of 18 million people, we have to export successfully to survive, and we have made great leaps and bounds. It is always a constant effort, and Austrade are to be congratulated on the effort that they make.

Australian exporters have done remarkably well against the odds over the last 12 months. In 1997-98, Australia's exports reached a record $114.2 billion—up 8.4 per cent on the previous financial year. Market diversification strategies are working. Our exports to non-East Asian markets grew at an average of 18.4 per cent in 1997-98. Exports rose by 41 per cent to the United States, 25 per cent to the European Union and 21 per cent to South Asia. Our very important market of Japan—which takes some 40 per cent of our exports—is in the most difficult grip of the Asian crisis, and we can only hope that they work through that because it is a very important market to us. Quite frankly, without our Japanese export markets we would all be starving.

The government has no illusion that 1999 will be anything but a difficult trading year. The growth prospects for the world economy are subdued and a number of our trading partners in Asia remain in recession. While our exports to East Asia grew at 5.7 per cent in 1997-98, figures for the calendar year 1998 show a softening due to the regional crisis. Global uncertainty emphasises the need to pursue market access opportunities on all fronts—multilaterally, regionally and bilaterally.

In the early weeks of 1999 there have been encouraging signs that trade will feature prominently on the international agenda this year. President Clinton's recent support for a new round of global trade negotiations is good news for the world economy and it is good news for Australia, but there remains much more to be done in coming months to secure wider support for a new round to shape the detail of future trade negotiations.

There is a very clear role for Australia in leading this debate. There are a number of initiatives that the government has already taken. Firstly, just last week the Deputy Prime Minister and trade minister, Mr Tim Fischer, visited Iran, which is most important for our wheat, Turkey, Indonesia and India. Secondly, legislation to extend the Export Market Development Grants Scheme for another two years will be introduced in this session. Thirdly, the government will launch in May a major new study on the prospective economic benefits of the millennium round of the WTO, which is being held later this year. Fourthly, for the first time we are seeking public submissions to help refine our WTO negotiating agenda. Fifthly, a new study is to be prepared on agrifood export opportunities to the Asian region—a very important priority for the government and one that has already been shown to be so by the Supermarket to Asia commitment.

The rationale behind our trade strategy is a simple one. Increasing our exports means more and better jobs for all Australians. Nearly 1.7 million Australian jobs—one in five, in fact—depend on exports. The strong trade framework we have put in place—as I said, multilaterally, regionally and bilaterally—the continuing strength of the Australian economy and the strong commitment of Australian industry to export quality goods and services mean that we are well equipped to deal with the opportunities and challenges in the coming year. And, as I said, Austrade is an integral part of that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I have had this report of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand in my hand only a short time, but it deals with an issue which in recent times has come to my notice. This is in relation to a twofold agreement. One is the 1994 agreement by the Coalition of Australian Governments—and that, in effect, is the various state governments with the Commonwealth government. That links into the competition policy agreement which was cemented rather ignominiously in legislation in 1995. However, what has come about is a fairly extensive framework for reform of the water industry. It is interesting that it is called the water industry. We are talking about an investment in Australia of over $90 billion of infrastructure and apparently annual revenues of $5 billion.

What is being looked at is the whole concept that water in Australia has not necessarily been priced or, if it has been priced, has not been priced consistently. Even within the environment movement there will be debate about the issue. I know there are various opinions as to whether or not you can protect or deal with the resource of rivers adequately by having tradeable water rights. But we do know that simply providing free access to anyone who happens to have a river running by their property does not necessarily mean justice. You cannot necessarily have someone dam a river and say, `This is mine,' because it affects people upstream and people downstream. It is now, I guess, the time when the various government bodies in Australia are trying to look at the issue of water quality, land and water degradation, and the conservation of a totally vital resource—fresh water, potable water and water for agriculture in Australia.

Water pricing, institutional arrangements, water allocation in trade and the environment, water quality, public consultation and education have all been looked at. As I said, this is linked to the national competition policy. How? Basically, it is part of the carrot and stick approach that the government has entered into with the state governments: if certain processes have been completed by specified dates, then the states gain some benefits through payments that come from the Commonwealth that have been set aside under national competition policy.

I realise that these issues have been the source of some debate in states like Queensland. I realise that various states have taken different approaches to this situation. It is interesting to note the statement by the ministers themselves. In the meeting communique of the meeting of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand in Adelaide on 20 November, the ministers state:

The Water Reform Framework agreed to by all Australian Governments in 1994 was developed against the background of concern about the state of the nation's water resources and the need to ensure sustainable development into the future.

This recognition is obviously very necessary. There does need to be further debate about the means by which this occurs and it should not be simply a means of privatising rivers or privatising access to rivers. It should be part of a process by which we work out what the needs are for our water resources, for rivers to continue to function—rivers clean, provide environmental resources and support eco systems—and for the economic functions that clean rivers provide. It is also an indication that, if we muck up this resource, we will be not only mucking up the environment but having a severe economic effect. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would probably be personally aware, in the north-west of Tasmania, the Drug Education Network Incorporated, under the direction of Elvie Hales, conducted a survey during 1997 amongst young people aged 12 to 18 years to examine the knowledge, perceptions and beliefs surrounding the use of the drugs cannabis, alcohol and tobacco as well as the levels and patterns of use of those drugs. While some studies have been conducted in other areas of Australia, at that time there had been no comparable studies undertaken in Tasmania which would provide up-to-date and locally based information.

speech.para: Fifteen schools, both government and non-government, participated, and a total of 1,264 students completed the specially designed questionnaire administered during normal school hours. Care was taken to ensure the uniformity of the environment during the administration of the questionnaire and variables were controlled as much as possible. The results of the study showed that participants' knowledge about drugs in general is varied.

While tobacco, cannabis and tranquillisers are acknowledged as drugs, 26 per cent thought that alcohol was not a drug. Some 32 per cent of participants reported they had tried cannabis in the past and 28 per cent said that they use cannabis now. Males reported a higher percentage of use, both past and present, than females. Levels of use increased with age, and `occasional use' and `at parties' are the most common times reported. Some 73 per cent of cannabis users report that they do not want to quit using cannabis.

A high percentage of participants, 91 per cent, said that there were health problems in using cannabis. Brain damage and memory loss were strongly identified as risks from using cannabis. However, the benefits of using cannabis for general pain relief and in the treatment of pain in cancer patients were also strongly identified. Relaxation and maintaining calmness was another reason for using cannabis, which was reported by a high percentage of participants. Peer pressure to use cannabis or not to use cannabis was identified as an issue for many participants. This pressure came from within the group to which the person belonged and desired to be part of. The risk of becoming addicted to cannabis was also identified.

Reported alcohol use among participants was quite higher than that of other drugs. Alcohol, for example, is used on a regular basis and within a broad range of social settings. Some 74 per cent said that they had used alcohol at some time in the past and 56 per cent said that they use alcohol now. The majority of those who reported that they use alcohol do so on an occasional basis or at weekends only. There is a low reported incidence of daily alcohol use, with slightly more males than females reporting daily use.

Beer is the most common alcoholic drink, closely followed by spirits and wine, or a combination of both. Males choose to drink more beer and females more wine and spirits. Some 84 per cent of participants reported that they do not want to quit using alcohol. While a very high percentage of participants recognised a general health risk from using alcohol, the risk of addiction, along with personality changes, was also acknowledged.

The main problem identified in relation to alcohol is the violence associated with its use—this from 12- to 18-year-olds in our community who are still mostly living at home. Of all the participants, 56 per cent said they have used tobacco in the past and 34 per cent said they use it now. Even though both males and females report the same percentages of having tried tobacco, the results indicate that more females than males say they use tobacco at present.

There is a marked difference in use levels between age groups, with an increasing usage trend reported as age actually increases. Of those currently smoking, 58 per cent report they would like to quit. General health issues, such as risk of cancer, heart disease and addiction, were identified.

Overwhelmingly, where participants reported a high level of use of a substance by family members and/or friends, they also reported using themselves. Conversely, where participants reported a low or nil level of use by family and/or friends, they reported a similar low level of their own use. Peer pressure does seem to play a part in influencing decisions about drug use and can help determine whether a person uses or not. The wish to be included in groups is an important component of this, and responses were consistent for all substances in the survey.

From the issues identified in the report, it was recommended that a working party be established to explore strategies and develop action plans and that the working party be made up of representatives from both government and non-government agencies, including the health and education sectors, police and local government. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Elvie Hales and her team from the Drug Education Network on such a comprehensive and enlightening report.

Research undertaken by my office indicates that people on the north-west coast of Tasmania are becoming more and more concerned about the increasing use of drugs and, alarmingly, we are told that the amount of drugs around is incredible. This has got to stop. Money is pouring into Tasmania for drug and alcohol problems, but we are told that a lot of it is wasted. It appears services are targeting the easy cases.

The crazed drug users are creating mayhem in our community. They are violent, out of control and highly manipulative. We must focus on these people and look at why they are like they are. It is alarmingly obvious that more of the same is just not working. We need a variety of programs for different types of drug users.

I believe that every thinking person in Australia must be very alarmed at our increasing crime rates. Not only do we have increasing crime rates; we have increasing violence associated with those crimes. Drug users need access to cash. They commit crimes and, drug crazed, they use violence.

It is common knowledge throughout the police force and, indeed, the community on the north-west of Tasmania that most burglaries and home invasions are related to drugs. We also have handbag snatching in supermarkets, elderly women robbed in broad daylight in city areas, elderly people bashed and robbed in their homes by intruders, drugs stolen from ambulances and armed hold-ups. It concerns me greatly that we have a federal government fighting drugs and state governments, through local police forces, policing drug users and supply. There does need to be greater coordination.

I am also concerned that we have a huge problem with powder drugs on the north-west coast of Tasmania, yet seldom do we read of drug busts. I ask: why not? The drugs issue is bigger than any of us have contemplated, and every Australian wants us as politicians to face up to it and do something about it. Tasmania, being an island within Australia, could be used as a test area for all drug related experiments, and I recommend this action to all levels of government. Drug related problems mostly stem from drug addiction. Why we develop drug addictions is the issue we must address. Soft options, I believe, are not the answer, neither is more of the same.

talk.start.para: —In the past few weeks, the government's Tough on Drugs initiative has come under increasing scrutiny. A Herald AC Nielsen poll indicated last week that almost two-thirds of people surveyed thought the Howard govern ment was doing a poor job on the drug problem. Mr Howard recently met with Mr Louis Freeh, from America's FBI, after expressing significant interest in implementing zero tolerance strategies as a means of addressing the country's growing drug problem.

speech.para: To most Australians, it is fairly obvious that there is very little logic in asking the Americans for help with our drug problem. The US has failed to arrest its ever increasing drug problem, despite years of `Just say no' drug education programs reinforced with rigorous policing measures. An examination of the American approach to solving the drug problem reveals a system that has metered out extreme punishments for years to the detriment of users and the broader community.

A recent article in the Seattle Times titled `Reduce crime without obscene prison-building binge' gives a good indication of widespread disillusionment with the American approach to the so-called war on drugs. Traditionally, the American answer to social problems such as drug addiction has been incarceration. Consequently, 1.8 million Americans are currently behind bars in federal and state prisons and local gaols.

America imprisons more of their citizens than any other nation on earth, including Communist China. They have the highest incarceration rate in human history for non-political offences. Some may interpret this to mean that all their dangerous criminals have effectively been rounded up and taken off the streets. Not so. Fewer than a third of American prisoners have committed a violent crime. Drug related cases predominate. Due to mandatory sentencing, drug offenders spend more time in gaol than rapists. The average sentence is 82 months for a drug offence and 73 months for rape.

Nelson Rockefeller introduced mandatory sentencing laws for drug offenders in the US in the 1970s. As a result, 1,000 new prisons were built across America in the 20 years that followed. These prisons are now full and overflowing. According to the Seattle Times article, California alone now has more inmates than France, Great Britain, Germany, Japan, Singapore and the Netherlands com bined—445 people per 100,000 are now in gaol.

The author of the article goes on to question whether crime could have been reduced in America without what he calls the `obscene prison-building binge'. He concludes in the affirmative, asserting that prisons in America have become nothing more than `a revolving door for poor, highly dysfunctional, often illiterate drug abusers'. The article asserts:
Diverting some of the billions now going to the prison-industrial complex for drug treatment and other prevention efforts could start us on a much saner course.

Another recent article, this time in the New York Times , bears further testimony to the rejection of zero tolerance strategies in the US. The article, titled `The War on Drugs Retreats, Still Taking Prisoners', points out the glaringly obvious, and that is that neither the US nor Australia can afford to fight a war on drugs based on complete prohibition for any extended amount of time. The article begins with some more extraordinary facts on incarceration rates in the US:
Every 20 seconds, someone in the United States is arrested for a drug violation. Every week, on average, a new jail or prison is built to lock up more people in the world's largest penal system.

The article contains comments from Barry McCaffrey, the four-star general who heads the National Drug Control Policy Office in the US. `We have a failed social policy and it has to be re-evaluated,' says General McCaffrey, `otherwise we're going to bankrupt ourselves because we can't incarcerate our way out of this problem.' General McCaffrey goes on to say that the quarter of a million Americans in prison for drug offences could be better dealt with in treatment programs, saving the taxpayer up to $5 billion a year.

It strikes me as somewhat strange that the Prime Minister is initiating talks with the FBI when there is another national body in the US working specifically to address the drug problem. If Mr Howard had talked to the experts in the National Drug Control Policy Office, he would already realise that zero tolerance is certainly not the way to go. Even more pertinent is the fact that, even if it were deemed to be a good idea, the drug problem in Australia is of such magnitude that we could not afford to build enough prisons to fit all the drug users in anyway!

A recent US study examining government data and independent research has drawn equally damning conclusions about the US drug policy to date. The Network of Reform Groups study concluded that the drug war has not deterred children from using illegal drugs, nor has it resulted in fewer deaths and injuries from drug use. In fact, drug overdose deaths are up 540 per cent since 1980. Thirty-three people per day are infected with HIV from injection drug use in the US. The price of heroin and cocaine has continued to drop since 1981, while the purity of both drugs has also increased.

It is time for the Prime Minister to stop ducking and weaving and to make some tough decisions. He needs to stop putting the taxpayers' money where his mouth is and wasting valuable resources on punitive zero tolerance measures that have already been proven ineffective overseas.

The availability of naltrexone is a valuable step toward increasing the treatment options available to Australian heroin users. Since 1 March, Australian GPs have been able to prescribe naltrexone for heroin addiction. Once again, however, the government's failure to grasp the magnitude or nature of heroin use has prevented a worthy initiative from delivering its potential benefits.

Mr Howard has overlooked the glaringly obvious need for naltrexone to be covered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Consequently, a month's supply of 30 tablets costs $280, putting the treatment out of the financial reach of many heroin users and their families. What is the point of releasing a new treatment when no-one can afford it? The point is supposed to be to reduce the incentive for users to commit property crime. How can this be achieved when treatment is so expensive?

I received a call last Thursday from a mother who has two sons using heroin. She was absolutely devastated because she had just found out how much it would cost her to treat them both with naltrexone, and she could not afford it. This lady had hoped that naltrexone might provide some hope for her sons who had failed on the methadone program. `Bitterly disappointed' does not go far enough to express how this mother felt when she found out she could not afford it. Mr Howard should not even entertain the notion of instituting zero tolerance policing when there is not enough money being spent on treatments that work.

It is now decision time for Mr Howard. Does he really want to emulate the American system by instituting the unsustainable mass incarceration of people for personal drug use? Does he really want to turn normal people into criminals, ultimately leaving no room in our gaols for rapists, murderers and the like? Does he want our gaols to become `revolving doors for poor, highly dysfunctional, often illiterate drug abusers'—as has occurred in the US?

I think it is time for him to put his own prejudices aside and recognise this problem as a health issue that can be addressed in the long term through a more thorough range of widely available treatment options. It would be foolish to follow the Americans down the zero tolerance road when it has failed to work, and they are now realising the benefits of treatment as opposed to incarceration.

In my opinion, the heroin trial is an inevitability in the long term. Last year in Australia, 600 people died from heroin use alone. It is not appropriate for the Prime Minister to be digging in his heels on a matter of life and death for many Australians. He should admit he made a mistake in panning the heroin trial, and let us have one as soon as possible so that this year some of those statistics might be avoided. The more treatment options we have up our sleeve, the more chance we have to successfully address the problem.

talk.start.para: —I refer to my adjournment speech in this chamber on 16 February this year, in which I highlighted the numerous serious problems with the aspect of the Constitutional Convention's model that deals with dismissal procedures for an Australian President. Today I would address yet other serious deficiencies with that model, this time in relation to the appointment procedure that it puts forward.

speech.para: That model is often referred to as a bipartisan or two-party model. For a start, presently in the House of Representatives there are three parties; and in the Senate, including Independents, there are six parties. So we start with a model which has an inaccurate and limited vision of our multiparty democracy.

As senators would be aware, the Constitutional Convention recommended that, in the event of Australia becoming a republic, the head of state should be nominated by the Prime Minister, seconded by the Leader of the Opposition, and finally approved by a two-thirds majority of a joint sitting of both houses. Putting to one side the merits of appointing an Australian President rather than electing one, senators should note that this model presents real problems of a constitutional nature from both legal and historical perspectives.

We obviously need to view the legislation that the government puts forward to go to referendum to see exactly how this model is to be transformed into law. I have had a look at the preliminary draft, and I am not reassured. Without pre-empting that process, it is important to appreciate that, at the least, the model as it stands will require entrenching into the Constitution the office of Prime Minister and office of Leader of the Opposition. These entities are hitherto unknown to the Constitution.

I do not want to address here the not insubstantial definitional and power issues that that exercise would entail but rather want to focus on the bold assumption contained in the model that a single formal Leader of the Opposition will continue to exist in Australian federal politics in the long term. Given that our Constitution needs to remain workable during the course of the 21st century, it is essential that such an assumption be soundly based.

Yet it is clear from our parliamentary history that the House of Representatives three-party system of today—with the coalition and Labor, notionally two parties—has not always been so entrenched. Up until 1931, for example, 30 years after Federation, the office of Leader of the Opposition—which of course to this day is not recognised in our Constitution—had no status in the standing orders of the House of Representatives. Further, the Liberal Party, as we now know it, was only formed in 1944 out of the remnants of the United Australia Party and 13 other anti-Labor organisations.

Looking to the experience of other countries is also instructive in terms of whether a notional two-party system is likely to remain in the longer term. Significantly, a survey of OECD nations reveals that, out of 29 countries, 23 have multiple parties in opposition as opposed to a formal single-party opposition.

Even in other Commonwealth countries with systems relatively firmly based on the Westminster tradition, and electoral systems as unrepresentative as that employed in our own House of Representatives, we have witnessed the emergence of strong new opposition parties. In Canada, for example, out of the 301 seats in their lower house, 145, or 48 per cent, are shared between four opposition parties. Even in the distorted electoral system of the United Kingdom's House of Commons, the Liberal Democrats have emerged as a genuine opposition party, currently holding a third the number of seats as are held by the Tories.

It is therefore apparent that the complexion of contemporary politics is considerably more flexible than has been the case for the last half century in Australia. Had fundamental electoral reform of the sort that has taken place in New Zealand occurred in Australia, these dramatic changes would have been enhanced.

The point of highlighting these facts is that, in the face of them, it would be naive in the extreme to simply assume that Australia's existing major party system will not undergo significant changes over the coming century. Therefore, proposed constitutional change should not be so short-sighted as to be founded on the view that the notional two-party system is here to stay.

Current practice in the House of Representatives is that official opposition status is conferred on that non-government party which has the numbers. In the event that the numbers do not make it clear who the official opposition is to be, it is for the Speaker to decide which group shall make up the official opposition. If it were the case that opposition parties with equal numbers were to be elected to the House of Representatives, it would be absurd—following the Constitutional Convention's bipartisan model—for the Speaker to be put in the position of choosing who was to second the prime ministerial nomination for President.

Taking this further, given that this process is apparently to be entrenched into the Constitution, the party in the House of Representatives not recognised by the Speaker to second the nomination could challenge the appointment of that President in the High Court. We would then have the intolerable situation of dragging the High Court into what is really a political matter—and this violates fundamentally the doctrine of separation of powers.

In view of these serious difficulties, a more flexible and far-sighted approach is required than one requiring mere bipartisanship. The Prime Minister should seek not just the agreement of the Leader of the Opposition for his or her nominee to be put to a vote in parliament but the backing of the leaders of all recognised parliamentary parties. This would allow the appointment of a President following an electoral outcome that gave rise to two or more distinct opposition parties in the lower house, without the constitutional dysfunction to which I have just alluded.

The other considerable benefit of this move is that parties elected in the Senate are given a voice in supporting the prime ministerial choice. This house, the Senate, should not be snubbed in the nomination process, especially given that our numbers, in terms of a joint house vote, will be overwhelmed by the members of the other place. This move would also help to eliminate the possibility of the present two major parties coming to some cosy arrangement that sees their past loyal servants taking the presidency in alternating terms. Such a scenario would be possible under the two-party model currently being put forward. Once entrenched in the Constitution, that would be practically impossible to change, given the vested interests of the major parties.

The Senate should ensure that structurally such an arrangement cannot be made. Requiring the support of the leaders of all parliamentary parties for the Prime Minister's nominee will do precisely this, ensuring that a consensus that better reflects the wishes of the Australian people is reached prior to the nominee being put to the vote. In closing, I should indicate that, despite the fact that I am seeking amendments to the bipartisan Constitutional Convention model, I remain convinced that the direct election option should be put to the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: —The uranium debate throughout the world has reached a point where I think it is rather negative. However, I intend to speak on this issue tonight in the minutes that are available to me. Australia is the Saudi Arabia of uranium deposits in the world. In other words, we have the biggest economically recoverable uranium reserves in the world, as Saudi Arabia has the comparable amount of oil in the world. We have 30 per cent of the world's known economic deposits, and we could mine about 650,000 tonnes of those on an $80 per kilo basis.

speech.para: During the eighties, there was a three-mine policy—effectively a two-mine policy—that inhibited and prohibited the export of uranium so that only two mines effectively operated. This policy cost Australia billions of dollars. One would have to ask what it achieved. It achieved nothing, except that it made the Rossing mine in Namibia the biggest in the world and it made Canada the biggest exporter in the world. Canada, with about 10 per cent of uranium deposits, had 30 per cent of exports of uranium. Australia, with 30 per cent of the world's reserves, now has 16 per cent, but it had much less than that in the eighties. South Australia has two deposits of uranium ready to be mined—the Beverley and the Honeymoon deposits—and the Jabiluka deposit in the Northern Territory is imminently mineable.

Uranium is a vexed issue with a lot of people, but what cannot be argued is that uranium is the cleanest, most efficient, cheapest and least dangerous—in terms of lives lost—form of generating electricity in the world. Australia exports to France, the United States, the United Kingdom, Sweden and Japan. Sweden is a model that the Labor Party and others opposite here tend to copy a lot. Certainly in my state of Western Australia, those discredited premiers during the eighties used Sweden as a model for Western Australia. Yet in those times Sweden generated 48 per cent of its electricity from uranium.

Among the 440 uranium power stations throughout the world, the United States at some of its nuclear power plants generates electricity at 2c a kilowatt hour or unit, as opposed to something like 8c, 10c or 12c a unit in Australia. We have lost, as I have mentioned, billions of dollars in export income because of the policy of not exporting uranium by the previous government. I see uranium as a commodity, one that is in demand throughout the world. If the recipients of our uranium meet the stringent criteria that the Australian government lays down with respect to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and others then we should continue to export uranium to them unless the destination conflicts with other Australian exporters of uranium.

I must say that the Western Mining Company had a delineated deposit at Yeelirie in WA that was effectively stopped by the Hawke administration and could have earned hundreds of millions of dollars in export income for Western Australia and Australia and would have generated hundreds of jobs in the process. This was not to be. In fact, during the election of the last Bannon government in South Australia, the federal government gave its permission to export and, as a result, gave the start-up to the Olympic Dam, one of the biggest uranium deposits and multi-metal deposits in the world. So it can be done.

What I do find surprising is that in Queensland in 1996 two Western Australian companies—Summit Resources and Resolute Ltd—were given permission by the then Minister of Mines and Energy in the Goss government to proceed with mining of uranium ore and exploration at the Valhalla deposit, which is about 40 kilometres north-west of the magnificent mining town of Mount Isa, which is represented, incidentally, so ably by the Hon. Bob Katter MHR, the member for Kennedy. What I find disturbing is that when the then minister in the Goss government, Mr McGrady, formed a government with Premier Beattie in Queensland, the new government said that it would never consider uranium mining. This is after the joint venture between Summit and Resolute had spent over $5 million in exploration and were prepared to spend another $8 million in exploration to delineate an economic deposit. That deposit, I understand, has a 20-year life and could have earned over $3½ billion over that period. What that has led to is the possibility of litigation and the recovery of damages by Summit Resources and Resolute Ltd, which were given permission by the then Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr McGrady, in 1996 under the Goss government, to proceed.

The futility of philosophically denying the export of uranium is borne out by the fact that Canada has increased its exports at the time that the Rio Tinto Zinc deposit in Namibia of Rossing became the biggest uranium mine in the world because of the inhibitions and the prohibition placed on the export of uranium ore from Australia. It meant nothing to the supply. All of those 440 and growing power stations throughout the world that use uranium as their heat medium flourished, producing cheap, unpolluting energy for the world. Some $3.6 billion will be lost to Queenslanders. One thousand jobs will be lost to Queenslanders in the construction stage of the Valhalla mine. A promise has been made that the joint venture partners will not fly in and fly out, as has been the practice of mining companies brought about by the iniquitous, unfair and, some would say, nefarious taxation policies applying to mining companies. These companies have promised and undertaken to have their work force live in Mount Isa.

You might recall, Mr Acting Deputy President Sherry, that the town of Mount Isa, a great mining town in Australia, one of the great mining towns of the world, which has produced millions of dollars in export income for Australia, has atrophied in the past decade from a population of over 30,000 down to just over 20,000. One-third of its population has been lost. Here is a company that was going to open up a new area, going to live in the town of Mount Isa, going to supply 230 permanent jobs, going to supply 1,000 jobs during its construction period, which was denied under the most duplicitous reasons of the Goss and Beattie governments.

I find that decision making and that duplicity very, very disturbing. It is not good for Australian mining companies. It is not good for Australia. It is not good for the reliability of our export commodities that we are known for. It is enough for this nation to struggle with respect to its mining with native title without having governments act in this manner. And if this is going to be duplicated in other areas of Australia all I can say is God help us. We in this country are known worldwide not just for our political stability but for the reliability of the supply of our resources. That is why Japan and other countries choose Australia above the other countries that supply commodities internationally. They choose Australia because of our political stability and the reliability of our supply.

I want to say in closing that this problem has to be rectified. I will support mining companies throughout Australia because they supply the standard of living that we have become used to. We cannot have a minister that on the one hand says, `Go ahead,' and then when he gets into a new regime and a new government with a new leader says, `It is all over. Go back to Western Australia.' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There has been much discussion on food and grocery prices and the expected impact of the tax reform package on these prices throughout Australia. This discussion has been particularly lively in the Northern Territory and has ranged across a variety of matters relating to the issue. I am concerned that Mr Snowdon, the federal member for the Northern Territory, gave a speech on 15 February in which he quoted from a report published by Territory Health Services on the impact on community stores. Mr Snowdon simplified a very complex issue in a devious manner for political ends and he did not give proper credit to that report—Survey of NT remote community stores —and the issues that it very properly raised about providing a better quality of food in those shops and a better standard of management that is so important in so many of these areas.

speech.para: The majority of communities in isolated areas require very special attention to the issues of consumers and supply in the whole process. There needs also to be a very special education process to make sure that store managers appreciate and do rely very heavily on what should be a store committee function and a store committee role. Groups like the Arnhem Land Progress Association do provide healthier food for members of the communities in which they operate. I implore those communities that do not have an active store committee to begin the process of developing one and to address any management problems that they have. In an increasingly litigious world one could envisage a possibility of a legal test case on a charge as serious as manslaughter against a store manager who has been negligent in supplying food not to a nutritious standard. The whole issue of lack of competition opens up issues for us in dealing with community stores and in fact also urban stores in Northern Australia.

The tax reform package will address many of these issues, both directly and indirectly. The changes that will come from providing much more consumable cash in the pockets of Territorians is important, but so are the diesel fuel excise changes and the wholesale sales tax removals. The income tax cuts, of course, are very important, but it is also important in this issue to look at the major grocery stores. The tax reform package will certainly impact on them, as I hope will the various reports of the Northern Territory committee that is currently looking into this matter in the Territory parliament on Territory food prices and the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector here in this place.

We need to look very carefully at the issues that should be canvassed and require investigation. Particularly, we need to look at the predatory purchasing practices of the major supermarket chains and at their purchasing, marketing and contractual arrangements in order to counter the very unfair and unscrupulous acts of many of those particular organisations. I believe there are questions that should be asked both of the Territory committee and the federal committee that go to the heart of the promotion of products in stores, and I will be making questions available to Dr Lim in the Northern Territory and Senator Boswell here in Canberra to ensure that these matters are properly pursued.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 10 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Have the guidelines for CDEP been changed.
(2) Is it permissible for CDEP to compete with private enterprise for contracts.
(3) If so, does this mean that Government subsidies are being used anti-competitively.
(4) If so, will the Minister review the guidelines to determine whether it is permissible for private corporations to contract with CDEP where CDEP is in competition with other small businesses.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The CDEP guidelines are changed when necessary to accord with reviews of the scheme or changes in other programs that interact with its administration. For example, some recent changes have been introduced in response to the Independent Review of the Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) Scheme (Ian Spicer's Report) and changes to Youth Allowance.

(2) In keeping with the CDEP Scheme's objectives to create employment, the guidelines permit the establishment of CDEP enterprises that may operate in a commercial environment. CDEP organisations that tender for private contracts are subject to the same regulation as their private sector competition.

(3) A primary objective of the CDEP scheme is to move participants into full time employment. In meeting this objective CDEP projects involved in the establishment of enterprises receive government subsidisation until they are able to operate independently. In the majority of these cases CDEPs are establishing business where none previously existed or where services are not provided. In this respect ATSIC does not consider the use of the program as being anti competitive.

(4) The aforementioned Spicer review, and associated economic development strategies for indigenous peoples, have recommended a greater role for CDEP in establishing indigenous businesses. Important considerations include developing a cooperative relationship with other businesses and/or measures such as joint venturing or partnership arrangements.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Surveillance Radar
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 344)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Is the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) radar at Williamtown being used in the Class G airspace trial technically inadequate for the task, on occasion not detecting aircraft in the airspace; and (b) is this because the RAAF radar was designed to do different tasks in different areas.

(2) Have Airservices Australia technicians altered the radar `mosaic', that is, which of the Mount Boyce, Sydney terminal approach radar and Kings Tableland radars provide coverage in which `squares' of the radar picture.

(3) Can it be confirmed that the RAAF surveillance radar (SURAD), the old `green screen' non-synthetic radar, can interrogate only one aircraft's radar transponder mode C altitude at a time, and only gives an instantaneous level read-out.
(4) Can it be confirmed that the RAAF SURAD is located in the tower and does not provide data labels, making it difficult to identify unknown traffic.

(5) Can it be confirmed that the RAAF has been opening all its restricted airspace, and for later in the evening, using the interim radar display system (IRDS) display downstairs in the approach cell.

(6) (a) Does this require four staff members to man the system and require the RAAF standing down its staff on Friday evening for the weekend; (b) does the RAAF have sufficient staff to provide this service long-term; and (c) is the RAAF meeting all costs associated with the delivery of this service.

(7) Can it be confirmed that the RAAF SURAD system is not compatible with IRDS, the Airservices Australia radar display system used in Brisbane and Sydney, and the system already has the maximum number of radar inputs available.
(8) Who will provide radar coverage from the Williamtown area during the Christmas break, when traditionally the military stand down for a month.
(9) What radar coverage is available outside RAAF hours, that is, down to what level in the Williamtown area.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: As the honourable senator would be aware the Class G Airspace trial was cancelled by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) in December 1998. However the following information is provided in response to your questions.

(1) (a) and (b) No, the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Air Traffic Control (ATC) at Williamtown use two radar systems, the Air Force Surveillance Radar system (SURAD) and the Interim Radar Display System (IRDS), which are regarded as complimentary and are not regarded as technically inadequate.

(2) Airservices Australia technicians did carry out some work to optimise low level radar coverage in the Williamtown-Taree area, as displayed on Airservices equipment. This involved adjustment to the radar mosaic. However, the results of this adjustment were equivocal. The original mosaic picture has been restored.

(3) Yes. The SURAD is an older generation radar that has been in service since the mid 1970's. Many older generation radars have inherent limitations of this nature when compared to newer equipment. However, this does not make them less safe, it just means that they do not possess some of the more `user-friendly' features of modern equipment.

The honourable senator may be interested to know that all SURAD radars across Defence will be phased out within the next two years and replaced with state-of-the-art radar systems purchased under Project AIR 5186, the Australian Defence Air Traffic System (ADATS).

ADATS will deliver the latest technology in the areas of primary solid-state radar and monopulse secondary surveillance radar. The system will provide all of the modern features, including automatic labelling and constant altitude updates.

(4) The RAAF SURAD radar picture is available in both the tower and approach control facilities. However, most of the control relating to the identification of air traffic occurs in the approach facility, not the tower.

Tower control is based on separation devised by controllers who visually sight traffic and issue control instructions. The SURAD picture in the tower is used by controllers, primarily, as an aid to acquire a traffic picture. The controller observes the radar position and then visually scans the corresponding area to sight the inbound aircraft.

On the occasions when tower and approach control are operating in what is referred to as `combined mode', approach control will be conducted using the tower SURAD screen. This, generally, only happens when limited services are required outside of normal operating hours, or when traffic density is very low.

With respect to difficulties in identifying unknown traffic, even modern labelled displays cannot perform this function unless the aircraft is in receipt of a transponder code and the aircraft's transponder is squawking, or transmitting, that code. The only other means of identification is for the controller and aircraft to be in two-way contact; which allows the aircraft to communicate a position, the controller to instruct the pilot to execute a turn which can be observed on radar, or for the controller to instruct the pilot to activate what is called a specific position indicator, or SPI, which generates an identification symbol on the controllers screen. SURAD is compatible with each of these methods

(5) During the Class G Airspace trial the RAAF ATC section at Williamtown provided additional services for a limited two-day period between 6am and 10pm on 4 and 5 November 1998 and from 6am and the commencement of normal RAAF flying operations on the morning of 6 November 1998. During these periods of extended services both the SURAD and IRDS systems were used to control traffic.

(6) (a) No. Normal services at Williamtown require a minimum of seven controllers to be on duty. As previously mentioned during the Class G Airspace trial this service was extended beyond normal operating hours for a limited two-day period, this extension of operating hours and the extra commitment was absorbed by the manning resources available.

Regarding the standing down of staff on Friday , this is normal practice at Williamtown, as RAAF flying at the base is, for the most part, conducted on weekdays. RAAF air control services are not available on weekends unless prior arrangements are made, and the activity requiring those services is deemed to be operationally essential.

(b) No, extended services would not have been able to be sustained long term. Air Force Headquarters had informed both Airservices Australia and the CASA that the RAAF would only extend operating hours for a limited period.
(c) Yes, the RAAF met all the costs associated with the limited period for which it supplied extended services.

Defence sees itself as having a responsibility to assist, where it can, in the management of the national airspace system. In this instance, existing resources allowed Defence to make a limited, but important, contribution towards the continuation of the Class G Airspace trial. Before that commitment was made there was extensive consultation with Headquarters Air Command, and the air traffic control section at Williamtown, to ensure that ATC resources allowed for the limited extension of operating hours. When it was established that Air Force could assist, the decision was made to provide extra services in the interests of aviation safety.

(7) Yes, the SURAD is not compatible with IRDS. However, this incompatibility does not compromise safety, as mentioned in the response to question 1 the SURAD and IRDS complement one another, one is used for low level close-in control, while the other is used for medium and high level activity.

Regarding the maximum number of radar inputs, as previously pointed out the SURAD is an earlier generation radar with limited capability when compared with modern systems, being an old system it was only designed to accept one input. That input comes for the radar antenna at the Williamtown base.
The Airservices Australia IRDS at Brisbane uses up to 4 inputs. Brisbane operates at capacity. Sydney can handle 4 but currently uses 3.
(8) This issue was addressed by the cancellation of the Class G Airspace trail.
(9) Radar coverage in the airspace surrounding Williamtown, outside those hours during which the RAAF provide a service, is the responsibility of Airservices Australia.

(2) When did Australia become a signatory to these provisions.
(3) When did the United States of America (US) become a signatory to these provisions.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The WTO Agreements do not contain provisions that require a member to report the existence, outbreak, or spread of a disease or pest in plants and plant products that may present a risk to industries in importing countries.

The International Plant Protection Convention (the IPPC) requires, however, in its Article VII, that each contracting party report periodically to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations, the existence, outbreak and spread of economically important pests of plants and plant products which may be of immediate or potential danger.

After the FAO system for disseminating such reports was disbanded two years ago due to lack of resources the IPPC was revised to provide an improved process for reporting incursions or outbreaks of plant pests and diseases. The necessary processes are under way in Australia to allow Parliament to decide whether it is in Australia's interests to ratify the revised IPPC.
(2) Australia became a member of the WTO on 1 January 1995 when the WTO entered into force.
Australia signed the IPPC on 30 April 1952 and ratified it on 27 August 1952.

The revised IPPC was approved unanimously by the FAO Council (of which Australia is a member) at its November 1997 session. Two-thirds of the contracting parties are required to ratify the new agreement for it to enter into force. The necessary processes are under way in Australia to allow Parliament to decide whether it is in Australia's interests to ratify the revised IPPC.
(3) The US became a member of the WTO on 1 January 1995 when the WTO entered into force.
The US signed the IPCC on 6 December 1951 and ratified it on 18 August 1972. The US is a member of the FAO Council which unanimously approved the revised IPPC at its November 1997 session.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, on 17 February 1999, the following question without notice:

question.para: Is it true that there are 2.4 million people employed in small business? Is it true that federal unfair dismissal applications for small business have halved to 2861, a minute percentage of those employees? Has the minister read the evidence from Australia Business Ltd (sic) that small business is woefully ignorant of the 1996 changes to the unfair dismissal provisions within the Workplace Relations Act? Since the government spent nearly $20 million telling Australians about tax before legislation was even introduced, how much has the government spent and how much does it intend spending on educating one million small businesses on the changes to the federal unfair dismissal laws which did pass the parliament and are working well and have halved the rate.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —In my reply I undertook to obtain further information:

answer.para: I have consulted the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and he has provided the following response:

According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, 1.3 million employees (excluding business proprietors) are employed in firms employing 15 or fewer employees (excluding agriculture). (Source: unpublished data from the ABS Business Growth and Performance Survey 1996-97 ).

Statistics obtained by the Australian Industrial Registry indicate that 35% of employers against whom federal unfair dismissal claims were made between December 1997 and December 1998 employed 15 or fewer employees. Applying this percentage to the total number of unfair dismissal applications filed annually, it is estimated that in 1998, 2865 applications were filed by persons employed in firms employing 15 or fewer employees, compared with 5087 such applications in 1996 and 2614 in 1997. Whilst the number of applications brought against employers employing 15 or fewer employees in 1998 was just over half the 1996 figure, it is relevant to note that there was an increase in applications in 1998 compared with the 1997 figure.

Whilst the number of small businesses that have been involved in federal unfair dismissal claims represents only a small percentage of the total number of small businesses, unfair dismissal laws, whether federal or State, are widely regarded by small business as a disincentive to engaging new employees. Small business concerns about the litigation risks of terminating staff translate into a concern about the hiring of new employees. This point has been made repeatedly through surveys and representations made by employer organisations on behalf of their members and by small employers directly. A small business need not have experienced an unfair dismissal claim in order to form a view that the laws are a disincentive to recruitment. There is a wealth of information about the operation of the laws in the public domain, including information produced by my Department that is specifically aimed at small business.

It should also be noted that the International Labour Organisation Convention No 158, on which the federal legislation is based, specifically contemplates a small business exemption from unfair dismissal laws.

The 1996 federal legislation introduced reforms to discourage baseless claims and make the hearing process fairer. However, it did not include any measures that would reduce the cost of defending a claim. It is the right of access to litigate in the jurisdiction against a small business that initiates concerns about the litigation risk.

The costs associated with preparing for and attending hearings and, where necessary, engaging specialist assistance, were unaffected by the 1996 changes. Any unfair dismissal system imposes preparation and hearing costs that compel many small businesses to settle claims for commercial reasons, irrespective of the merits of the application. The risk of being pressured into settling a baseless claim is a significant issue for small businesses, irrespective of the jurisdiction in which they operate, as the majority report of the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business & Education Legislation Committee Inquiry into the Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998 indicated. The payment of money to dismissed employees to settle unmeritorious claims is overlooked by Senator Murray when he says that 53% of claims are settled in favour of employers. That figure relates to less than ten per cent of the total applications dealt with by the AIRC since 31 December 1996. It is the percentage of arbitrated claims determined in favour of employers, plus applications that were dismissed before conciliation because there was no jurisdiction or because an extension of time to apply was refused. Most cases are settled either during the conciliation process, or after conciliation but before arbitration. Payments are commonly made to settle unmeritorious claims. This has been made clear in representations made to me by small businesses and by employer organisations on their behalf, as well as extensive submissions put to the recent Senate Inquiry.

The (then) Department of Industrial Relations conducted an information and education campaign when the Workplace Relations Act 1996 commenced. The cost of this campaign, which included a national telephone helpline, targeted newspaper advertising, written material and seminars was $244000.

I am advised that in addition to the general information and education campaign, my Department has, since January 1997, conducted over 160 seminars on Employment and Termination issues. These seminars have covered good recruitment practices and employer obligations generally as well as unfair dismissal laws. The seminars have been conducted in capital cities and major country centres and have been attended by about 14000 people. A further round of seminars is scheduled to commence in March 1999. The government is already doing, in an appropriate way, what Senator Murray suggests should be done. The costs of these seminars are met through the payment of registration fees by participants.

The Department also produced a handbook called Managing Employment and Termination Issues, which is a practical guide for employers. It was first produced in 1995, and then revised in 1997 to take account of the 1996 legislative changes. Approximately 17000 copies the 1997 version of the handbook have been sold.
I am also advised that the Department's web site includes four publications that provide information on the unfair dismissal laws;
- The Workplace Relations Act: A Guide for Micro Business
- Workplace Relations for Small Business
- A `Fact Sheet' (which is a basic guide) on Termination of Employment and Unfair Dismissal
- A User Guide (which is a more detailed publication than the fact sheet) on termination of employment.
In addition, both employers and employees have access to advice on the unfair dismissal laws through the Department's telephone enquiry service.

It would, however, be wrong to conclude that educating and informing small businesses about the unfair dismissal jurisdiction would ameliorate these problems. Indeed, the opposite could quite possibly be the case. Whilst education and information sharing is not opposed in principle, the disincentive

impact is evident when those businesses with experience in the jurisdiction inform other small businesses, employer organisations and policy makers about those experiences. Small businesses exposed to the actual level of regulation and complexity in the workplace relations system (for example, in awards, unfair dismissal jurisdictions and statutory obligations) could understandably be even more concerned about the level of workplace regulation than they already are.
